events.title: Birth of Angelina Milka
events.description: Angelina Milka was born.

events.title: Birth of Nikola Tesla
events.description: Nikola Tesla was born in Smiljan, in the then Austro-Hungarian Empire.

events.title: Nikola Tesla's Education
events.description: In 1861 he attended the primary school in Smiljan, studying German, arithmetic and religion

events.title: Tesla Family Moves to Gospić
events.description: In 1862 when the Tesla family moved to Gospić, Nikola attended primary school and then the Lower Real Gymnasium

events.title: Nikola Tesla's Illness
events.description: Nikola Tesla was seriously ill with cholera for at least nine months

events.title: Nikola Tesla's Graduation
events.description: Nikola graduated from the Higher Real Gymnasium, at Karlovac

events.title: Nikola Tesla Avoids Military Draft
events.description: In 1874 he avoided being drafted into the Austro-Hungarian army by running away to Tomingaj, near Gračac in the mountains

events.title: Nikola Tesla's Enrolment at the Austrian Polytechnic
events.description: In 1875 Tesla enrolled at the Austrian Polytechnic in Graz on a Military Frontier scholarship

events.title: Nikola Tesla Leaves University
events.description: In December 1878 Nikola Tesla left Graz and broke off all contact with his family to hide the fact he had dropped out of school

events.title: Death of Angelina Milka
events.description: Angelina Milka died.

events.title: Nikola Tesla Returns to Gospić
events.description: In March 1879 Tesla was returned to Gospić under police guard for not having a residence permit

events.title: Death of Nikola Tesla's Father
events.description: His father died a month later in April 1879

events.title: Nikola Tesla Leaves for Prague
events.description: In January 1880 two of his uncles put together enough money for Tesla to leave for Prague to continue his studies

events.title: Nikola Tesla Moves to Budapest
events.description: Tesla moved to Budapest in early 1881 and began working for the American Telephone Company

events.title: Tesla moves to Paris
events.description: Tesla left for Paris in the Spring of 1882 to work for Edison’s European operation, the Continental Edison Company.

events.title: Tesla's financial struggle
events.description: Tesla was struggling financially, spending his wages very quickly and finding the last 29 days of the month tough.

events.title: Tesla arrived in New York
events.description: Batchelor gave Tesla an excellent reference for him to give to Edison after he reached New York.

events.title: Tesla Electric Light Company founded
events.description: After leaving Edison, Tesla set up the Tesla Electric Light Company to produce arc lighting equipment with the financial help of two investors, Robert Lane and Benjamin Vail.

events.title: Tesla Electric Company founded
events.description: In 1886 Alfred S. Brown, a Western Union superintendent, and Charles F. Peck a New York attorney, gave Tesla financial backing and the three men set up the Tesla Electric Company at 89, Liberty Street, Manhattan.

events.title: Demonstration at the American Institute of Electrical Engineers
events.description: Tesla's polyphase induction motor which ran on AC was patented and demonstrated at the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

events.title: War of the currents
events.description: A licensing deal was arranged and Westinghouse hired Tesla for 12 months to be a consultant to the Westinghouse company’s Pittsburgh laboratories. This conflict became known as the War of the Currents.

events.title: Nikola Tesla becomes a naturalised American
events.description: Nikola Tesla became a naturalised American.

events.title: Establishment of Tesla's Laboratories in New York
events.description: In 1891, Tesla established laboratories in New York, first in South Fifth Avenue and then in East Houston Street.

events.title: Development of the Tesla Coil
events.description: The Tesla coil, an air-core transformer with primary and secondary coils tuned to resonate, was developed.

events.title: Tesla becomes a naturalized American Citizen
events.description: In July 1891, Tesla became a naturalized American citizen.

events.title: Merger of Edison General Electric with the Thomas Houston Company
events.description: In 1892 Morgan merged Edison General Electric with the Thomas Houston Company which had abandoned DC and moved to AC.

events.title: Merger of Edison General Electric and Thomas Houston Company
events.description: Morgan merged Edison General Electric with the Thomas Houston Company which had abandoned DC and moved to AC.

events.title: Westinghouse Wins Bid to Light World’s Columbian Exposition
events.description: In 1893, Westinghouse won the bid to light the World’s Columbian Exposition (a World’s Fair) in Chicago with AC. He beat General Electric by bidding one million dollars.

events.title: Construction of First Hydroelectric Plant in the USA
events.description: In 1893, Westinghouse won the contract to produce the AC system electrical generators for the first hydroelectric plant to be built in the USA: at Niagara Falls.

events.title: Fire at Tesla’s Fifth Avenue Laboratory
events.description: In March 1895, a fire at Tesla’s Fifth Avenue laboratory destroyed much of his early work including invention models, plans, notes, laboratory data, tools and photographs valued at US$ 50,000.

events.title: Nikola Tesla's work with X-rays
events.description: Tesla lost interest in X-rays and moved his attention to radio transmission after Röntgen’s discovery.

events.title: Tesla's Experiments with X-Rays
events.description: In the early months of 1896, Tesla experimented with X-rays. His interest was, however, short-lived.

events.title: John Trowbridge's X-ray Image
events.description: John Trowbridge, Professor of Physics at Harvard, used the Tesla system to make an X-ray image in 1.5 minutes.

events.title: Tesla's Radio Transmission Experiments
events.description: Tesla conducted experiments on the possible transmission by radio waves in the Gerlach Hotel, New York.

events.title: Electrical Review
events.description: Tesla N. featured in Electrical Review

events.title: The use of the Röntgen X-rays in surgery
events.description: Keen WW. Discusses the use of the Röntgen X-rays in surgery. McClure’s Magazine 6: 579–588

events.title: Reflection of X-rays
events.description: Tesla N. discusses the reflection of X-rays in Nature 53: 615

events.title: Tesla's Report on X-Rays
events.description: In June 1896, Tesla reported that exposure of the head to a powerful X-radiation produced a general soothing effect, a sensation of warmth in the cerebral lobes, and a tendency to sleep.

events.title: Scientific American suppl 41: 17053
events.description: Tesla N. featured in Scientific American suppl 41: 17053

events.title: Electrical World 28: 127
events.description: Discussion in Electrical World 28: 127

events.title: Scientific American 75: 185
events.description: Discussion in Scientific American 75: 185

events.title: Purchase of Tesla’s AC patents
events.description: In 1897, Westinghouse Electric Company purchased Tesla’s AC patents for a lump source payment of US$ 216,000.

events.title: Tesla's X-ray tube circuit
events.description: Tesla designed an X-ray tube circuit.

events.title: Journal of the Franklin Institute 143:212
events.description: Discussion in Journal of the Franklin Institute 143:212

events.title: On the hurtful actions of Lenard and Röntgen tubes
events.description: Tesla N. discusses the hurtful actions of Lenard and Röntgen tubes. Electrical Review 30: 207, 211

events.title: Demonstration of Radio-Controlled Boat
events.description: Tesla demonstrated a radio-controlled boat, which he called a Telautomaton, at an electrical exhibition in Madison Squares Gardens.

events.title: Burning from a vacuum tube not generating X-light
events.description: Rollins W. discusses the burning from a vacuum tube not generating X-light. Electric Review

events.title: Tesla conducts high-voltage experiments
events.description: Tesla studied atmospheric electricity, produced artificial lightening, and caused a power outage during an experiment.

events.title: Tesla receives funding from John Jacob Astor IV
events.description: John Jacob Astor IV invested US$ 100,000 for Tesla to develop a new lighting system. Tesla used the funding for his high-voltage, high-frequency experiments.

events.title: Tesla in Colorado Springs
events.description: Tesla spent time in Colorado Springs, presumably working on his projects.

events.title: Tesla moves lab to Colorado Springs
events.description: Tesla relocated his laboratory to Colorado Springs to conduct his high-voltage, high-frequency experiments.

events.title: Tesla left Colorado Springs
events.description: Tesla left Colorado Springs and his laboratory was demolished and the contents sold to pay off some of his debts.

events.title: Tesla's Patents for Electrical Transmission and Transmitter
events.description: Tesla was granted patents for a system of transmitting electrical energy and an electrical transmitter.

events.title: Start of the Wardenclyffe Tower project
events.description: Tesla started on a project to build the Wardenclyffe Tower funded by J. Pierpoint Morgan, for trans-Atlantic wireless communications.

events.title: First Transatlantic Radio Transmission
events.description: Marconi made the first transatlantic radio transmission.

events.title: Construction of the Wardenclyffe Tower
events.description: The 187 foot tower was erected during 1901–1903 as part of Tesla’s planned but never completed “World Wireless System”

events.title: The control of guinea pigs
events.description: Rollins W. discusses the control of guinea pigs. Boston Medical & Surgical Journal

events.title: Tesla's handwritten note to Sir William Crookes
events.description: Tesla wrote a note to Sir William Crookes which was included in a multiple exposure picture for the Century Magazine by the photographer Dickenson Alley.

events.title: Vacuum tube burns Boston Medical & Surgical Journal
events.description: Rollins W. discusses vacuum tube burns in the Boston Medical & Surgical Journal

events.title: Upholding of Tesla's Patents
events.description: Tesla's patents over radio transmission were upheld.

events.title: Reversal of Decision in Favour of Marconi
events.description: The decision on the patent battles over radio transmission was reversed in favour of Marconi.

events.title: Demolition of the Wardenclyffe Tower
events.description: The tower was finally demolished.

events.title: Tesla moves into the New Yorker Hotel
events.description: In 1934 he moved into the New Yorker Hotel in downtown Manhattan which was a lower class of hotel than he was used to.

events.title: Death of Nikola Tesla
events.description: Nikola Tesla died in New York City.

events.title: Restoration of Tesla's Prior Patents
events.description: The US Supreme Court restored the prior patents of Tesla.

events.title: Death of Nikola Tesla
events.description: Tesla collapsed on the evening of 7 January 1943 in his hotel room. He had suffered a heart attack.

events.title: Obituary of Nikola Tesla
events.description: New York Times publishes an obituary of Nikola Tesla

events.title: Naming of the Système International (SI) unit of magnetic flux density
events.description: The Système International (SI) unit of magnetic flux density was named as the Tesla, denoted by the capital letter T.
